item.title: Brits in their 40s-60s are screwing it up
item.description:
Colin Angus on Twitter

‚ÄúDeaths in England & Wales from drug poisoning (in red) and alcohol-specific causes (in blue) have different age profiles, but rates of both have risen sharply in the last few years, particularly in people in their 40s-60s.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/victimofmaths/status/1582660632482308096?s=46&t=X2G85Ib__u4547d-91qhdg

item.title: Eels
item.description:
Dr Eelmily Finch on Twitter

‚ÄúOk folks. It‚Äôs time we talked about eels. I‚Äôm a geologist but I recently learnt about eels and‚Ä¶ wow. Since then, I‚Äôve been greeting strangers with ‚ÄòDO YOU KNOW ABOUT EELS?!‚Äô Well, consider yourself a stranger in my path. Strap in. It‚Äôs a üßµ 1/so many‚Äù

Lawrence H. Summers on Twitter

Lawrence H. Summers on Twitter

‚ÄúI am disappointed by the tendentious & selective analysis of team transitory acolytes who keep finding new arguments for their conclusion that inflation is @ to subside & policy should be dovish. I focus on @paulkrugman because he is so clear & smart. 1/N https://t.co/hCEI9uEzWO‚Äù

item.title: The Covid baby bump
The relative academic decline of American Jews
item.description:
Eric Kaufmann on Twitter

‚ÄúThe reality Kanye has missed is that the Jewish presence in the American elite is falling, and quickly. Jews were as much as 20% of Ivy League student body in 2000, down to 7% today (@TheFIREorg data), and this shift is glaring among elite academics (1,200 sample):‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/epkaufm/status/1581969375526985729

Fiscal dominance vs. monetary dominance in the UK
item.description:
Jason Furman on Twitter

‚ÄúInstead of the fiscal dominance I had feared the UK is now experiencing monetary dominance. Monetary policymakers are not keeping rates low to support a fiscal expansion, instead fiscal policymakers are turning contractionary to prevent large rate rises.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/jasonfurman/status/1581991901498343425
